Venerable ÅšÄriputra said
Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully translated by imperial decree
Chapter on the Six Dharmas, Part One of Chapter Seven on the Six Dharmas. At that time, ÅšÄriputra again said to the assembly:
Venerable ones, you should know that the Buddha himself has thoroughly understood and realized the six dharmas, and has proclaimed and revealed them to his disciples.

We should now gather together to compile them, so that there will be no disputes after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a. We should cause the Dharma and Vinaya of the holy life to abide for a long time, benefiting immeasurable beings, and having compassion for the heavenly and human beings of the world, enabling them to attain supreme benefits and happiness.
What are the six dharmas?
There are two Udanas here.
The first UdanÄ says:
The first six dharmas are of ten kinds, namely internal, external, consciousness, contact,
Feeling, perception, thought, craving, regression, and non-regression, each with six.

There are six internal sense bases, six external sense bases, six groups of consciousness, six groups of contact, six groups of feeling, six groups of perception, six groups of volition, six groups of craving, six factors leading to retrogression, and six factors leading to non-retrogression.
What are the six internal sense bases?
Answer:
First, the internal sense base of the eye;
Second, the internal sense base of the ear;
Third, the internal sense base of the nose;
Fourth, the internal sense base of the tongue;
Fifth, the internal sense base of the body;
Sixth, the internal sense base of the mind.
What is the internal sense base of the eye?
Answer:
If the eye has already seen, is now seeing, or will see forms, or if it is of the same kind, this is called the internal sense base of the eye.
The internal sense bases of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind should be explained in the same way, according to the appropriate context.
What are the six external sense bases?
Answer:
First, the external sense base of forms;
Second, the external sense base of sounds;
Third, the external sense base of smells;
Fourth, the external sphere of taste;
Fifth, the external sphere of touch;
Sixth, the external sphere of mental objects.
What is the external sphere of form?
Answer:
If form is seen by the eye, either already seen, now seen, or to be seen, or if it is of the same kind, this is called the external sphere of form.
The external spheres of sound, smell, taste, touch, and mental objects should be explained in detail as appropriate.
What are the six groups of consciousness?
Answer:
First, the group of eye consciousness;
Second, the group of ear consciousness;ğŸ”½Third, the group of nose consciousness;
Fourth, the group of tongue consciousness;
Fifth, the group of body consciousness;
Sixth, the group of mind consciousness.
What is the group of eye consciousness?
Answer:

The eye and various forms give rise to eye consciousness. In this, the eye is the dominant condition, and form is the object. The nature of discrimination, the nature of ultimate discrimination, and the nature of discriminating form regarding forms cognized by the eye, this is called the group of eye consciousness.
The body of ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness should be explained in detail as appropriate.
What are the six bodies of contact?
Answer:
First, the body of eye contact;
Second, the body of ear contact;
Third, the body of nose contact;
Fourth, the body of tongue contact;
Fifth, the body of body contact;
Sixth, the body of mind contact.
What is the body of eye contact?
Answer:
The eye and various forms give rise to eye consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, there is contact.

Here, the eye is the dominant factor, and form is the object. The contact that is cognized by the eye, the contact with form, the nature of equal contact, the contact that has been contacted and will be contacted, is called the body of eye contact.
The bodies of ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact should be explained in detail as appropriate.
What are the six bodies of feeling?
Answer:ğŸ”½First, the body of feeling produced by eye contact;
Second, the body of feeling produced by ear contact;
Third, the aggregate of feeling born from nasal contact;ğŸ”½Fourth, the aggregate of feeling born from gustatory contact;
Fifth, the aggregate of feeling born from tactile contact;
Sixth, the aggregate of feeling born from mental contact.
What is the aggregate of feeling born from visual contact?
Answer:
The eye and various forms serve as conditions to give rise to visual consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, there is contact. Because of contact, there is feeling.

Here, the eye is the dominant condition, form is the objective condition, visual contact is the cause. Visual contact gives rise to, is the type of, is born from, and is produced by visual contact. Associated with attention, it is the feeling, etc. of the eye, the various feelings, the discrimination of feelings, the already felt, and the to-be-felt that are cognized by the eye. This is called the aggregate of feeling born from visual contact.
The aggregates of feeling born from auditory, olfactory, gustatory, tactile, and mental contact should be explained in the same way, as appropriate.
As for the six aggregates of perception, what are they?
Answer:
First, the aggregate of perception born from visual contact;
Second, the aggregate of perceptions arising from ear-contact;ğŸ”½Third, the aggregate of perceptions arising from nose-contact;
Fourth, the aggregate of perceptions arising from tongue-contact;
Fifth, the aggregate of perceptions arising from body-contact;
Sixth, the aggregate of perceptions arising from mind-contact.
What is the aggregate of perceptions arising from eye-contact?
Answer:
Eye and various forms serve as conditions to give rise to eye-consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, there is contact. Because of contact, there is perception.

Here, the eye is the dominant condition, form is the object, eye-contact is the cause, eye-contact is the origination, eye-contact is the type, eye-contact is the production, eye-contact is the arising, and the attention associated with it is the thought of various forms cognized by the eye, the equal thought, the present thought, the past thought, and the future thought. This is called the aggregate of perceptions arising from eye-contact.
The aggregates of perceptions arising from ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, and mind-contact should be explained in the same way, according to the circumstances.
What are the six aggregates of volition?
Answer:
First, the aggregate of volition born from eye contact;
Second, the aggregate of volition born from ear contact;ğŸ”½Third, the aggregate of volition born from nose contact;
Fourth, the aggregate of volition born from tongue contact;
Fifth, the aggregate of volition born from body contact;
Sixth, the aggregate of volition born from mind contact.
What is the aggregate of volition born from eye contact?
Answer:
Eye and various forms serve as conditions to give rise to eye consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, there is contact. Because of contact as a condition, there is volition.

Here, the eye is the dominant condition, form is the object, and eye contact is the cause. Eye contact gives rise to, is the type of, is born from, and is produced by eye contact. It is associated with attention.

Regarding forms cognizable by the eye, all volitions, volitions of equal status, present volitions, volitions of the past and future, and mental activities that make the mind act are called the aggregate of volition born from eye contact.
The aggregates of volition born from ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact should be explained in detail as appropriate.
As for the six bodies of craving, what are the six?
Answer:
First, the body of craving born from eye contact;
Second, the body of craving born from ear contact;ğŸ”½Third, the body of craving born from nose contact;
Fourth, the body of craving born from tongue contact;
Fifth, the body of craving born from body contact;
Sixth, the body of craving born from mind contact.
What is the body of craving born from eye contact?
Answer:
Eye and various forms give rise to eye consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, there is contact. Because of contact, there is feeling. Because of feeling, there is craving.

Here, the eye is the dominant condition, and form is the object. The craving, etc. for the forms cognized by the eye, the grasping, storing, guarding, attachment, fondness, and love, are called the body of craving born from eye contact.
The bodies of craving born from ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact should be explained in detail as appropriate.
As for the six factors conducive to regression, what are the six?
Answer:
First, not dwelling in respect for the Buddha;
Second, not dwelling in respect for the Dharma;
Third, not dwelling in respect for the Saá¹…gha;
Fourth, not dwelling in respect for learning;
Fifth, possessing evil speech;
Sixth, encountering evil friends.
As for not dwelling in respect for the Buddha, what is the nature of not being respectful towards the Buddha?
Answer:

The nature of not being respectful, not being equally respectful, not being in a state of mastery, and not being equally in a state of mastery towards the World-Honored Buddha, this is called the nature of not being respectful towards the Buddha.
It is the same for the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, and learning.
As for possessing evil speech, what is the nature of evil speech?
Answer:
As explained before with evil speech.
As for encountering evil friends, what is the nature of evil friends?
Answer:
As explained before with evil friends.
As for the six factors conducive to non-retrogression, what are the six?
Answer:
First, dwelling in respect for the Buddha;
Second, to abide with respect for the Dharma;
Third, to abide with respect for the Saá¹…gha;
Fourth, to abide with respect for learning;
Fifth, to possess good speech;
Sixth, to encounter good friends.
As for abiding with respect for the Buddha, what is the nature of respect for the Buddha?
Answer:

The nature of respect for the World-Honored Buddha is the nature of respect, the nature of granting autonomy, and the nature of turning according to fear and autonomy. This is called the nature of respect for the Buddha.
It is the same for the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, and learning.
As for possessing good speech, what is the nature of good speech?
Answer:
As explained before, good speech.
As for encountering good friends, what is the nature of good friends?
Answer:
Good friends refer to the Buddha and the Buddha's disciples, and so on, up to practicing the abandonment of delusion and the taming of deluded conduct. This is called the nature of good friends.
If one is able to associate with, closely associate with, attend upon, and serve such a good friend, this is called encountering a good friend.
The following uddÄna:
The last six have fourteen, namely joy, sorrow, equanimity, and constancy,
The realms, leaving, faculties, joy, supernormal powers, clarity, mindfulness, higher views, and types.

There are six types of joy, six types of sorrow, six types of equanimity, six constants, six realms, six realms of leaving, six roots of conflict, six delightful dharmas, six supernormal powers, six thoughts that lead to clarity, six recollections, six unsurpassed dharmas, six contemplations, and six types of birth.
What are the six types of joy?
Answer:
First, having seen forms with the eyes, one delights in forms;
Second, having heard sounds with the ears, one delights in sounds;
Third, having smelled fragrances with the nose, one delights in fragrances;
Fourth, when the tongue tastes flavors and delights in them, it is the practice of approaching flavors.
Fifth, when the body feels touches and delights in them, it is the practice of approaching touches.
Sixth, when the mind cognizes dharmas and delights in them, it is the practice of approaching dharmas.

As for the practice of approaching forms that are delightful when seen with the eyes, it means that when the eyes see forms, one contemplates with a mind that delights in forms that are entirely lovable, entirely enjoyable, entirely delightful, and entirely agreeable.

If one gives rise to the feeling of joy that arises from contemplating forms with a mind that delights in them, this is called the practice of approaching forms that are delightful when seen with the eyes.
The practices of approaching joy with the ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this.
What are the six practices of approaching sorrow?
The answer is:
First, the practice of approaching forms that are sorrowful when seen with the eyes;
Second, the practice of approaching sounds that are sorrowful when heard with the ears;
Third, the practice of approaching smells that are sorrowful when smelled with the nose;
Fourth, the bodily faculty experiences tangible objects and gives rise to unpleasant feelings.
Fifth, the mind cognizes dharmas and gives rise to unpleasant feelings.
Sixth, the mind cognizes dharmas and gives rise to feelings of equanimity.

As for the eye seeing forms and giving rise to unpleasant feelings, it means that when the eye sees forms, it uses thoughts that give rise to unpleasant feelings towards forms that are completely unlikable, completely unenjoyable, completely unappreciable, and completely disagreeable.
If, due to using thoughts that give rise to unpleasant feelings towards these forms, feelings of sorrow arise, this is called the eye seeing forms and giving rise to unpleasant feelings.
The unpleasant feelings of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also like this.
What are the six feelings of equanimity?
The answer is:
First, the eye sees forms and gives rise to feelings of equanimity.
Second, the ear hears sounds and gives rise to feelings of equanimity.
Third, the nose smells fragrances and gives rise to feelings of equanimity.
Fourth, the tongue experiences tastes and then abandons them, approaching tastes.
Fourth, the bodily faculty experiences tangibles and then abides in equanimity with regard to tangibles;
Fifth, the mind cognizes dharmas and then abides in equanimity with regard to dharmas.

As for the eye seeing forms and then abiding in equanimity with regard to forms, it means that when the eye sees forms, with regard to forms that are neither lovable nor unlovable, neither enjoyable nor unenjoyable, neither delightful nor undelightful, neither agreeable nor disagreeable, one abides in equanimity with regard to them.
If equanimity arises due to abiding in equanimity with regard to these forms, this is called the eye seeing forms and then abiding in equanimity with regard to forms.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind abiding in equanimity are also like this.
What are the six abidings?
The answer:
First, having seen forms with the eye, one neither delights nor grieves, but abides in mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity;

Second, having heard sounds with the ears, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity.ğŸ”½Third, having smelled fragrances with the nose, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity.
Fourth, having tasted flavors with the tongue, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity.
Fifth, having felt tactile objects with the body, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity.
Sixth, having cognized mental phenomena with the mind, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity.

As for having seen forms with the eye, one is neither delighted nor distressed, but endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, always abiding in equanimity, it means that when the eye sees forms, whether they are lovable or unlovable, enjoyable or unenjoyable, delightful or undelightful, agreeable or disagreeable, or whether they are the basis, the immediately preceding condition, the object, the location, or the dominant condition, one contemplates them with the thought of equanimity.

If one contemplates this form with the thought of the faculty of equanimity, the bliss that arises is called the bliss of equanimity. When one sees forms with the eyes, one neither delights nor grieves, but is mindful and fully aware, always abiding in equanimity.
The same applies to the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
Question:
What is meant by equanimity in this context?
Answer:
The nature of the mind being impartial, the nature of the mind being upright, and the nature of the mind dwelling spontaneously without agitation should be known as equanimity in this context.
Furthermore, some say that the feeling of equanimity associated with the six consciousnesses and taking form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and mental objects as objects is called equanimity.

In this meaning, it should be known that the nature of the mind being impartial, the nature of the mind being upright, and the nature of the mind dwelling spontaneously without agitation, the practice of equanimity is called equanimity.
What are the six elements?
Answer:
First, the earth element;
second, the water element;
third, the fire element;
fourth, the wind element;
fifth, the space element;
Sixth, the consciousness realm.
Distinguishing these six is like the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
What are the six realms of renunciation?
Answer:
First, there is a venerable one who says:
Although I have already cultivated and practiced the meditation on loving-kindness many times, my mind is still bound by anger.
One should tell him:
Do not say that.
Why is it so?
If there is a venerable one who has already cultivated and practiced the meditation on loving-kindness many times, there is no possibility that his mind is still bound by anger.
If the mind is still bound by anger, it is impossible.
This means that the meditation on loving-kindness is definitely able to free one from all bonds of anger.
Question:
What is meant by renunciation in this context?
Answer:
Permanently severing the bonds of anger is also called renunciation, transcending the bonds of anger is also called renunciation, and all meditations on loving-kindness are also called renunciation.
In this meaning, the intention is to speak of the name of the concentration of loving-kindness as liberation.
Second, there is a venerable one who says like this:
Although I have already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the concentration of compassion, my mind is still bound by harm.
One should tell him:
Do not say this.
Why is it so?
If there is a venerable one who has already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the concentration of compassion, there is no possibility that his mind is still bound by harm.
If the mind is still bound by harm, it is impossible.
It is said that the concentration of compassion must be able to liberate from all bonds of harm.
Question:
What is meant by liberation in this context?
Answer:
The permanent severance of the bonds of harm is also called liberation, transcending the bonds of harm is also called liberation, and all concentrations of compassion are also called liberation.
In this meaning, the intention is to speak of the name of the concentration of compassion as liberation.
Third, there is a venerable one who says like this:
Although I have already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the joy-mind concentration, my mind is still bound by unhappiness.
One should tell him:
Do not say so.
Why is it so?
If there is a venerable one who has already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the joy-mind concentration, there is no possibility that his mind will still be bound by unhappiness.
If the mind is still bound by unhappiness, it is impossible.
It is said that the joy-mind concentration is definitely able to depart from all unhappiness.
Question:
What is meant by departing in this context?
Answer:
Permanently severing unhappiness is also called departing, transcending unhappiness is also called departing, and all joy-mind concentrations are also called departing.
In this meaning here, the intention is to speak of the joy-mind concentration as departing.
Fourth, there is a venerable one who says like this:
Although I have already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the concentration of the mind of equanimity, my mind is still bound by lust, greed, and hatred.
One should tell him:
Do not say so.
Why is it so?

If there is an elder who has already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the concentration of the mind of equanimity, there is no possibility that his mind will still be bound by lust, greed, and hatred.
If the mind is still bound by lust, greed, and hatred, it is impossible.
Because the concentration of the mind of equanimity is able to depart from all lust, greed, and hatred.
Question:
What is meant by departing in this context?
Answer:

The permanent abandonment of lust, greed, and hatred is also called departing; transcending lust, greed, and hatred is also called departing; all concentrations of the mind of equanimity are also called departing.
In this meaning, the intention is to speak of the concentration of the mind of equanimity as departing.
Fifth, there is an elder who says:
Although I have already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the formless concentration of mind, my mind is still bound by the consciousness that follows characteristics.
One should tell him:
Do not say so.
Why is it so?

If there is an elder who has already practiced, cultivated, and done much in the formless concentration of mind, it is impossible and cannot happen that his mind is still bound by the consciousness that follows characteristics.
If the mind is still bound by the consciousness that follows characteristics, it is impossible.
Because the formless concentration of mind must be able to transcend all consciousness that follows characteristics.
Question:
What is meant by transcendence in this context?
Answer:

Permanently severing the consciousness that follows characteristics is also called transcendence, surpassing the consciousness that follows characteristics is also called transcendence, and the formless concentration of mind is also called transcendence.
In this meaning, the formless concentration of mind is referred to as transcendence.
Sixth, there is an elder who says:
Although I have distanced myself from self-conceit and do not view the self and what belongs to the self, my mind is still bound and harmed by the arrow of doubt and indecision.
One should tell them:
Do not speak like this.
Why is it so?

If there is a venerable one who has distanced themselves from self-conceit and does not view the self and what belongs to the self, there is no possibility that their mind will still be bound and harmed by the arrow of doubt and indecision.
If the mind is still bound and harmed by the arrow of doubt and indecision, it is impossible.
It is said that one who has distanced themselves from self-conceit and does not view the self and what belongs to the self will certainly be able to transcend all doubt and indecision.
Question:
What is meant by transcendence in this context?
Answer:
The permanent abandonment of self-conceit is also called transcendence, and the surpassing of self-conceit is also called transcendence.
In this meaning, the intention is to say that surpassing all conceit is called transcendence.
What are the six roots of disputes?
Answer:
It is said that there is a type of person who has anger and resentment, and if one has anger and resentment, one cannot respectfully make offerings, revere, and praise the great teacher.

If one cannot respectfully make offerings, revere, and praise the great teacher, then one does not see the Dharma. If one does not see the Dharma, then one does not care about Å›ramaá¹‡as. If one does not care about Å›ramaá¹‡as, then one gives rise to defilement, mockery, and disputes.

Giving rise to defilement, mockery, and disputes as a basis causes many beings to experience meaninglessness, lack of benefit, and suffering. This can lead to meaninglessness, lack of benefit, and suffering for immeasurable devas and humans.

If you see such roots of disputes, whether internal or external, that have not yet been eliminated, you should gather together in harmony and diligently seek to eliminate them without being negligent.
You should cause such roots of disputes to be completely eliminated without remainder, as if they had not yet arisen.

If you see that internally or externally they have all been eliminated, you should then arouse right mindfulness and right understanding, a sharp and vigorous mind, and diligently guard against them, causing them never to arise again in the future. This is called right elimination, the good elimination of the roots of disputes.

If there is anger and resentment, if there is concealment and vexation, if there is jealousy and stinginess, if there is deceit and flattery, if there is wrong view and inverted view, the extensive explanation is also like this.
Furthermore, there is a type of person who clings to their own views, giving rise to firm grasping and being difficult to teach to abandon them.

If one clings to one's own views, giving rise to firm grasping and being difficult to teach to abandon them, then one will be unable to respectfully make offerings, revere, and praise the Great Teacher.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If one is not able to respectfully make offerings, revere, praise, and extol the great teacher, then one will not see the Dharma. If one does not see the Dharma, then one will not care about Å›ramaá¹‡as. If one does not care about Å›ramaá¹‡as, then one will give rise to defilements, contempt, and disputes. Due to giving rise to defilements, contempt, and disputes as a basis, one will cause many beings to experience meaninglessness, lack of benefit, and suffering. This will lead to immeasurable meaninglessness, lack of benefit, and suffering for gods and humans.
If you see that internally or externally there is something that has not yet been eliminated, you should gather together and unite in diligently seeking its elimination, without being negligent.
You should cause the roots of disputes to be eliminated without remainder, as if they had not yet arisen.

If you see that internally or externally they have all been eliminated, you should then give rise to right mindfulness, right knowledge, and a sharp mind to diligently guard against their future arising. This is the right elimination of the roots of disputes.
There is anger, resentment, or there is concealment, vexation, or there is jealousy, stinginess, or there is deceit, flattery, and so on, all as explained above.
As for those with wrong views and inverted views, what are wrong views?
Answer:

All views that there is no giving, no sacrifice, no love, and so on, up to no self-realization that one's births are exhausted, the holy life is established, what was to be done is done, and one does not receive later existences, are called wrong views.
As for inverted views, it refers to precisely wrong views, whose views are inverted.
As for grasping one's own views and giving rise to firm attachments that are difficult to abandon when taught, what is grasping one's own views?
Answer:

Adhering to the view that the self and the world are permanent, only this is true and the rest is foolish delusion, and so on, up to adhering to the view that after the TathÄgata's death he neither exists nor does not exist, only this is true and the rest is foolish delusion, this is called grasping one's own views.
What is giving rise to firm attachments?
Answer:
It is precisely because of attachment to one's own views that one gives rise to firm grasping.
How is it difficult to make them abandon [their views]?
Answer:
Because one gives rise to affection, equal affection, and manifest affection for one's own views, therefore it is difficult to make them become disgusted and liberated.
As for the six delightful dharmas, what are the six?
Answer:
If there are bhiká¹£us who give rise to loving physical actions towards the Great Teacher and those who practice the same pure conduct as themselves, this is called the first delightful dharma.

Because of this dharma, one can give rise to what is delightful, can give rise to what is respected, can give rise to what is agreeable, can attract what is delightful, respected, agreeable, pleasing, and joyful, and can embrace and delight in it without opposition or dispute, and unify it.

Furthermore, if there are bhiká¹£us who give rise to loving verbal actions towards the Great Teacher and those who practice the same pure conduct as themselves, this is called the second delightful dharma.
Because of this dharma, one can give rise to what is delightful, and so on, up to unifying it without dispute.
Moreover, there are bhiká¹£us who give rise to the mind of kindness towards the Great Teacher and those who practice the same pure conduct as themselves. This is called the third agreeable dharma.
Because of this dharma, they are able to give rise to what is lovable, and so on, up to being without dispute and having one destination.

Moreover, there are bhiká¹£us who obtain proper offerings in accordance with the Dharma, even if it is only food and drink received in the alms bowl. They share and enjoy these offerings equally with those who practice the same pure conduct as themselves, without hiding anything separately. This is called the fourth agreeable dharma.

Because of this dharma, they are able to give rise to what is lovable, and so on, up to being without dispute and having one destination.ğŸ”½Moreover, there are bhiká¹£us whose precepts are without deficiency, without gaps, without mixture, without defilement, worthy of offerings, without grasping, well-completed, well-received, praised by those with wisdom and without blame. They uphold these precepts equally with those who practice the same pure conduct as themselves, without hiding anything. This is called the fifth agreeable dharma.
Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Because of this Dharma, one can give rise to what is lovable, and so on up to non-disputation and one-pointedness.

Furthermore, there is a bhiká¹£u who, regarding all views as noble and liberating, is well able to penetrate them. If one gives rise to and creates them, one can correctly end suffering. Regarding such views, one studies and practices together with those who have wisdom and are of the same pure conduct, without hiding anything. This is called the sixth delightful Dharma.

Because of this Dharma, one can give rise to what is lovable, what is respectable, what is agreeable, and can attract what is lovable, respectable, agreeable, and delightful, and bring about acceptance, joy, non-opposition, non-disputation, and one-pointedness.
Regarding the Great Teacher, what is the Great Teacher?
The answer is:
All TathÄgatas, Arhats, and Perfectly Enlightened Ones are called the Great Teacher.
And those who have wisdom and are of the same pure conduct, what are those who have wisdom and are of the same pure conduct?
The answer is:
KÄtyÄyana and so on are called those who have wisdom and are of the same pure conduct.
As for the practice of loving-kindness with the body, what is the practice of loving-kindness with the body?
Answer:
The bodily actions that arise together with compassion and pity, this is called the practice of loving-kindness with the body.

This practice of loving-kindness with the body is present in harmony with the Great Teacher and those who are wise and practice the same pure conduct as oneself. For this reason, it is said that the practice of loving-kindness with the body towards the Great Teacher and those who are wise and practice the same pure conduct as oneself is called the first delightful Dharma.

This means that such Dharma is able to accord with what is very lovable, to nourish and beautify what is worthy of offerings, and to be always diligent in perfecting the requisites. Therefore, it is called delightful Dharma.

That which can give rise to what is lovable means that by this Dharma one is able to give rise to what is lovable.ğŸ”½That which can give rise to what is respected means that by this Dharma one is able to give rise to what is respected.
That which can give rise to what is agreeable means that by this Dharma one is able to give rise to what is agreeable.

That which can lead to what is lovable, respectable, agreeable, delightful, accepted, joyful, free from conflict, and harmonious means that by this Dharma one can lead to what is lovable, respectable, agreeable, delightful, accepted, joyful, free from conflict, and harmonious.
Here, accepted means to bring together.
As for harmonious, it means to be harmonious with a single object and a single flavor.
Just as with loving physical actions, loving verbal and mental actions should be understood in the same way.
By the Dharma one obtains the Dharma's offerings and services - how does one obtain the Dharma's offerings and services by the Dharma?
The answer is:

If offerings and services are not obtained through pretense, not obtained through deception, not obtained through displaying signs, not obtained through incitement, and not obtained through seeking profit with profit, and when enjoying them no guilt arises, it is called obtaining the Dharma's offerings and services by the Dharma.
Even to the food and drink received in the bowl, means even to the food and drink that fall into the bowl are still to be enjoyed together, let alone other wealth and goods.

What is meant by all the precepts?
Answer:
The pure bodily actions, speech actions, and livelihood of those without outflows are all called all the precepts.

Without deficiency, without gaps, without mixture, without defilement means that in this precept one always acts and always turns, equally acting and equally turning, and therefore it is called without deficiency, without gaps, without mixture, without defilement.

As for worthy of offerings, it means that sentient beings with greed, anger, and delusion are called servants. If sentient beings are free from greed, anger, and delusion, they are called worthy of offerings, worthy of receiving offerings of clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, etc., because they are always to be worshipped.
As for without grasping, it means that the noble disciples do not give rise to grasping or clinging to the precepts.
Well completed means that in this precept one guards well, protects well, and reaches the ultimate completion.
Well received and taken up means that in this precept one is reverent and respectful, and fully embraces it.

Praised by the wise, without blame means that the buddhas and their disciples are called the wise. All these wise ones together praise it and do not find fault with it. For this reason, it is said that it is praised by the wise, without blame.
As for upholding this kind of precepts together with wise practitioners of pure conduct without concealment, what is meant by this kind of precepts?
Answer:
It refers to the precepts of equality.
The precepts of equality refer to right speech, right action, and right livelihood among the eightfold noble path, which are called the precepts of equality.

As for all views, what are called all views?

Answer: If based on the wholesome dharmas born from renunciation and detachment, there is thorough discernment and thorough investigation of the characteristics of dharmas, and so on, this is called all views.
This is the noble renunciation, and so on, as explained in detail above.
As for practicing together with those who have knowledge and are of the same spiritual practice without hiding anything, what is meant by such a view?
Answer:
It refers to the view of equality.
The view of equality refers to right view among the eightfold noble path, which is called the view of equality. The rest is explained as before.

What is the higher knowledge of spiritual powers?
Answer:
Experiencing and manifesting various spiritual powers, and so on, is called the higher knowledge of spiritual powers.
Question:
What is meant by higher knowledge here?
Answer:
The marvelous cognition regarding all spiritual powers.
What is the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear?
Answer:
Hearing various sounds with the divine ear, such as human sounds, non-human sounds, distant sounds, near sounds, and so forth, this is called the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear.
Question:
What is meant by supernormal in this context?
Answer:
The marvelous cognition regarding the sphere of the divine ear.
What is the supernormal knowledge of knowing the minds of others?
Answer:

One can truly know the minds of other sentient beings and individuals, such as their thoughts and contemplations, knowing a greedy mind as it truly is as a greedy mind, and a mind free from greed as it truly is as a mind free from greed. Similarly, one can know an angry mind and a mind free from anger, a deluded mind and a mind free from delusion, a contracted mind and a distracted mind, a defiled mind and an undefiled mind, an undirected mind and a directed mind, an untrained mind and a trained mind, an unliberated mind and a liberated mind, all as they truly are. This is called the supernormal knowledge of the minds of others.
Question:
What is meant by supernormal knowledge in this context?
Answer:
It is the marvelous knowledge of the minds of others and so forth.
What is the supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives?
Answer:
It is the ability to recollect past lives, immeasurable in the past, such as one lifetime, and so forth. This is called the supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives.
Question:
What is meant by supernormal knowledge in this context?
Answer:
The marvelous cognition of past abodes.
